article:
On the night of the play, Jack was at the theatre early. He was already dressed in a policeman's clothes long   _   the end of the first scene. He certainly looked the part all right, he thought as he   _   himself in the mirror. He even   thought of   going out into the street to see whether he could pass as a policeman out there. Just for   _  , of course.
Then he suddenly felt   _  . After all, it was his first time to have a part in a play How could he    _   all those people watching the play? He put his head in his hands and tried to   _   his lines, but nothing came to his   _  .
A knock on the door made him   _   up. He was to go on stage in the second   scene    `  . "Have I missed my part and   _   the play for everybody?" he thought to himself.   _   it was only the manager. She   _   how nervous he was and suggested he should stand near the   _   where he could watch and follow the play. It was a good   _   of getting rid of his nervousness, she said. She was right, it seemed to   _  . In fact the more he watched the play, the more he felt himself part of it.
At last the   _   came for him to appear on the stage. But suddenly the manager came to him again, looking   _   as she placed a hand on his arm to hold him back. "Has anything gone   _  ?" Jack asked. "I'm afraid you're going to be disappointed," she said. "They've   _   three pages of the play and have missed your part out completely."
